note: The plural form 'מילים' (milim) is grammatically masculine, despite the singular 'מילה' (milah) being feminine.

example_sentences.note: 'הביתה' (habaytah) is a directional form meaning 'homeward' or 'to home'.

note: Spelled the same as the masculine singular present tense of the verb 'לאכול' (le'ekhol - to eat).

example_sentences.translation_english: There is a lot of food on the table.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: هناك الكثير من الطعام على الطاولة.

example_sentences.translation_english: I am eating an apple now.

note: This noun is always grammatically plural (pluralia tantum), even when referring to a single body/instance of water.
This is an irregular verb. The infinitive form differs significantly from the present tense forms (e.g., הולך - holekh).

example_sentences.translation_english: He is walking in the street.

note: The masculine singular present tense form 'אוכל' (okhel) is spelled the same as the noun 'אוכל' (okhel - food).

example_sentences.translation_english: I want to talk to you.

note: Pronunciation varies: usually 've', changes to 'u' before letters ב, ו, מ, פ or a shva, and 'va' before certain vowel combinations.
Pronunciation varies: usually 'be', changes to 'ba' when attached to a word with the definite article (בּ + ה = בַּ).

example_sentences.translation_english: The book is on the table.

note: Although the plural form ends in ות (-ot), this noun is grammatically masculine.

example_sentences.translation_english: There is a book on the table.

note: Although the plural form ends in ות (-ot), this noun is grammatically masculine.

example_sentences.translation_english: There are three doors in the room.

note: Although the plural form ends in ות (-ot), this noun is grammatically masculine.

example_sentences.translation_english: I am writing with a pen.

note: Although the plural form ends in ות (-ot), this noun is grammatically masculine.

example_sentences.translation_english: I am working on the computer.
There are many computers in the office.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: هناك العديد من أجهزة الحاسوب في المكتب.

note: Although the plural form ends in ות (-ot), this noun is grammatically masculine.

example_sentences.translation_english: There are many cars on the road.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: هناك العديد من السيارات على الطريق.

note: The plural form עָרִים ('arim) is irregular.

example_sentences.translation_english: I live in a big city.
There are many cities in Israel.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: هناك العديد من المدن في إسرائيل.

example_sentences.translation_english: There are three rooms in the apartment.

note: Kesef is generally used in singular form in modern Hebrew for the concept of money.

example_sentences.translation_english: I need money to buy a book.
I need money to buy a book.

note: Zman is generally used in singular form for the concept of time.

example_sentences.translation_english: It takes a lot of time.
There are many people in the street.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: هناك الكثير من الناس في الشارع.

example_sentences.translation_english: The boy is playing in the park.
The girl is reading a book.
There are many girls in the class.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: هناك العديد من الفتيات في الصف.

example_sentences.translation_english: I work in a big company.
He is a good Hebrew teacher.
The teachers in the school teach well.
The students are studying for the test.
The doctor told me to rest.

example_sentences.hebrew: יש הרבה רופאים טובים בעיר הזו.
example_sentences.translation_english: There are many good doctors in this city.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: هناك العديد من الأطباء الجيدين في هذه المدينة.

example_sentences.translation_english: The doctors (f) work in a hospital.

example_sentences.hebrew: אני הולך לבית ספר כל יום.
example_sentences.translation_english: I go to school every day.

example_sentences.hebrew: יש הרבה בתי ספר טובים בעיר.
example_sentences.translation_english: There are many good schools in the city.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: هناك العديد من المدارس الجيدة في المدينة.

example_sentences.translation_english: He studies at the university in Tel Aviv.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: هو يدرس في الجامعة في تل أبيب.

example_sentences.translation_english: There are several universities in Israel.
Shall we go to a restaurant this evening?
example_sentences.translation_arabic: هل نذهب إلى مطعم هذا المساء؟

example_sentences.translation_english: There are many good restaurants in the city.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: هناك العديد من المطاعم الجيدة في المدينة.

example_sentences.translation_english: I bought food at the supermarket.
There are big supermarkets in the city.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: يوجد سوبر ماركت كبيرة في المدينة.

example_sentences.translation_english: I went to the bank to withdraw money.
There are many banks in the city center.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: يوجد العديد من البنوك في وسط المدينة.

example_sentences.translation_english: The children are playing in the park.
There are beautiful parks in the city.
I am walking in the street.
There are many shops on this street.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: يوجد العديد من المتاجر في هذا الشارع.

example_sentences.translation_english: We will meet in the city square.
There are large squares in Tel Aviv.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: يوجد ساحات كبيرة في تل أبيب.

example_sentences.translation_english: I watch television in the evening.

note: 'Radio' often doesn't change in plural in common usage

example_sentences.translation_english: I listen to the radio in the car.
I read a newspaper in the morning.

example_sentences.translation_arabic: يوجد العديد من المجلات المثيرة للاهتمام.

example_sentences.translation_english: I sent a letter to my friend.
I received a package by mail.

note: This noun is typically used in the plural form in modern Hebrew
Note: נעליים is grammatically a dual form but used as plural
Often used in singular for the concept, but has plural forms too depending on context.
Mass noun, typically singular
Typically singular
Typically singular

example_sentences.hebrew: אני מעדיף תה על פני קפה.

example_sentences.translation_english: I want a glass of orange juice.
There are different types of juices.
There are many fresh fruits in the market.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: يوجد الكثير من الفواكه الطازجة في السوق.

example_sentences.translation_english: I buy vegetables at the market.
He works six days a week.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: هو يعمل ستة أيام في الأسبوع.

example_sentences.translation_english: I don't sleep well at nights.

example_sentences.hebrew: אני גר כאן כבר כמה חודשים.
example_sentences.translation_english: I have been living here for several months already.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: أنا أعيش هنا منذ عدة أشهر بالفعل.

example_sentences.translation_english: Three years have passed since then.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: مرت ثلاث سنوات منذ ذلك الحين.

example_sentences.translation_english: I want to see a movie.
She is listening to music now.
He calls me by my name.
I need to write a letter.
The children are happy to play.

example_sentences.hebrew: הם היו עצובים לשמוע את החדשות.
example_sentences.translation_english: They were sad to hear the news.
The book is there on the table.

example_sentences.hebrew: אני תמיד קורא ספר לפני השינה.
example_sentences.translation_english: I always read a book before sleep.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: أنا دائماً أقرأ كتاباً قبل النوم.

example_sentences.translation_english: Sometimes I go to the park.
Who is coming to the party?
What is your name? (Lit. How do they call you?)
How many books did you (m.sg) buy?
I have a meeting on Monday.

example_sentences.hebrew: יש לנו ארוחת ערב ביום שישי.

example_sentences.translation_english: I drink coffee in the morning.

note: Grammatically dual/plural

example_sentences.translation_english: We will meet at noon/in the afternoon.
It will take a few minutes.
It happened within a few seconds.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: حدث ذلك في غضون ثوانٍ قليلة.

example_sentences.translation_english: The book is on the table.
I am going to the school.
I bought a gift for you (m.sg).
I received a letter from a friend.
The book is on the table.
We are talking about the movie.

example_sentences.hebrew: אני הולך לבית ספר עִם חברים.
example_sentences.translation_english: I go to school with friends.
Did you (m.sg) drink the coffee with milk?

note: Possessive particle, similar to 'of' or '-s' in English.

example_sentences.translation_english: This is Moshe's book. / This is the book of Moshe.
If it rains, we will stay home.
I will come if I can.
The food is tasty, but expensive.
I wanted to come, but I couldn't.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: أردت أن آتي، ولكن لم أستطع.

example_sentences.translation_english: He came, and she did too.

note: Literally 'even once not'.

example_sentences.hebrew: ראיתי את זה אף פעם לא.

note: Also used as 'you're welcome'.

example_sentences.translation_english: Thank you very much! You're welcome.
Excuse me, where is the restroom?

note: Used for 'hello', 'goodbye', and 'peace'.
Literally 'to see each other'.

example_sentences.hebrew: הוא תמיד אומר בֹּקֶר טוֹב כשהוא נכנס.
example_sentences.translation_english: He always says good morning when he enters.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: هو دائماً يقول صباح الخير عندما يدخل.

example_sentences.translation_english: We met and said good evening.

example_sentences.hebrew: הילדים אמרו לַיְלָה טוֹב והלכו לישון.
example_sentences.translation_english: The children said good night and went to sleep.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: قال الأطفال ليلة سعيدة وذهبوا للنوم.

example_sentences.translation_english: The ball is on the table above.

example_sentences.translation_arabic: الأطفال في الطابق السفلي / في الأسفل.

example_sentences.translation_english: He is standing in front of me.
He is sitting next to the window.
My house is near the park.

note: Similar to לְיַד but can sometimes imply directly 'on the hand of'.

example_sentences.translation_english: The book is next to the bed.
The phone is inside the bag.

note: Used for negative commands (don't).

example_sentences.translation_english: He suddenly got up and left.
First we ate, and then we went to the movie.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: أولاً أكلنا، ثم ذهبنا إلى السينما.

example_sentences.hebrew: אני עייף, אָז אני אלך לישון.
example_sentences.translation_english: I'm tired, so I will go to sleep.
This is according to the agreement.
He is fast like the wind.

example_sentences.hebrew: עשיתי את זה בִּשְׁבִיל המשפחה שלי.
example_sentences.translation_english: I did this for my family.

example_sentences.hebrew: אני עייף כִּי לא ישנתי טוב.
example_sentences.translation_english: I'm tired because I didn't sleep well.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: أنا متعب لأنني لم أنم جيداً.

example_sentences.translation_english: He said that he will come.
We had a lot of joy.
I was filled with joy when I heard the news.
He felt a lot of sadness.
His eyes were full of sadness.
I spoke to him in anger.
He had no hate in his heart.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: لم يكن لديه كراهية في قلبه.

example_sentences.translation_english: There is a tall tree in the garden.
The table is made of wood.
I gave her a red flower.
The garden is full of beautiful flowers.
The sun shines in the morning.
A beautiful day with a lot of sun.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: يوم جميل مع الكثير من الشمس.

example_sentences.translation_english: We saw the moon in the sky.
The sky is full of stars.

note: Always plural in Hebrew.

example_sentences.translation_english: The birds are flying in the sky.

note: Can mean land, country, or earth.

example_sentences.translation_english: We are going to the sea today.
There are many fish in the sea.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: يوجد الكثير من السمك في البحر.

example_sentences.translation_english: There is a bridge over the river.
You can see many mountains from the window.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: ترى الكثير من الجبال من النافذة.

example_sentences.translation_english: The house is built on a small hill.
There are many hills in this area.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: يوجد الكثير من التلال في هذه المنطقة.

example_sentences.translation_english: This is the way to school.
There is a bridge over the river.
The farmers are working in the field.
The fields are green in the spring.
There are many trees in the forests.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: يوجد الكثير من الأشجار في الغابات.

example_sentences.translation_english: It's very hot in the desert.
There is little life in the deserts.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: توجد القليل من الحياة في الصحاري.

example_sentences.translation_english: I saw a small insect on the wall.
There are many insects in the garden.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: يوجد الكثير من الحشرات في الحديقة.

example_sentences.translation_english: The sky is full of migrating birds.
The cat (female) is sleeping on the chair.
We saw many cats in the street.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: رأينا الكثير من القطط في الشارع.

example_sentences.translation_english: We saw many horses on the farm.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: رأينا الكثير من الخيول في المزرعة.

example_sentences.translation_english: We saw cows in the field.
I need to think about it.
I will send you a letter.
I want to buy a new book.
They want to sell the car.

example_sentences.hebrew: הוא רוצה לְהַשְׂכִּיר את הדירה שלו.
example_sentences.translation_english: He wants to rent out his apartment.
She rented out a room to a student.
We need to rent a car.
They want to build a house.
We need to set a date for the meeting.
I don't want to be late.
Don't disturb me when I'm working.
The food is about to run out.
I want to suggest an idea.
I want to ask for help.
They need to convene a meeting.
He gathered everyone in the room.
It's hard to interpret this dream.

example_sentences.hebrew: הוא פירש את המילים שלי לא נכון.

example_sentences.translation_english: We like to hike in nature.
We want to invite the guests.
I need to fix the computer.

note: Followed by a verb in the infinitive.
Used impersonally or with a subject, followed by an infinitive.

example_sentences.translation_english: She needs to study for the test.

note: Used impersonally, meaning 'it is possible' or 'can'.

example_sentences.translation_english: Is it possible to open the window? / Can I open the window?
example_sentences.translation_arabic: هل من الممكن فتح النافذة؟ / هل يمكنني فتح النافذة؟

note: Used impersonally, meaning 'it is not possible' or 'cannot'.

example_sentences.translation_english: It is impossible to do that. / You cannot do that.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: من المستحيل فعل ذلك. / لا يمكنك فعل ذلك.

example_sentences.translation_english: It is impossible to enter. / You cannot enter.
We are playing against the other team.
They are sitting opposite each other.
He is standing behind the door.
The sun is setting behind the mountains.

note: Can refer to time or place.

example_sentences.translation_english: He is standing in front of the house.

note: Can refer to time or place.

example_sentences.translation_english: The book is under the table.
The bird flew over the house.
The sun is above our heads.
He is sitting between mom and dad.

note: The infinitive of 'to be'. Often implied in present tense.

example_sentences.translation_english: I want to be a doctor.
We need to go up the stairs.
They want to get off the bus.
I need to finish the work.
I hope to succeed on the test.
The child is babbling on the phone.

example_sentences.hebrew: אני צריך לְאַרְגֵּן את החדר שלי.
example_sentences.translation_english: I need to organize my room.

example_sentences.hebrew: אני רוצה לְשַׁפֵּר את העברית שלי.
example_sentences.translation_english: I want to improve my Hebrew.

note: Often used to mean 'wonderfully' or 'amazingly'.

example_sentences.translation_english: I bought a dress like this (feminine).
There are many interesting places to visit.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: يوجد الكثير من الأماكن المثيرة للاهتمام للزيارة.

example_sentences.translation_english: I have a few things to say.

note: Can mean 'once', 'time' (as in occurrence), or 'suddenly' (in the construct state).

example_sentences.translation_english: How many times have you been there?

note: Refers to validity or expiration.

example_sentences.translation_english: What is the validity of the passport?
The card is valid for a year.

note: Used to transition or express a change in topic/thought, sometimes like 'anyway' or 'so'.

example_sentences.translation_english: Anyway, what did you do today?
example_sentences.translation_arabic: على أي حال، ماذا فعلت اليوم؟

example_sentences.translation_english: It was difficult, but we succeeded anyway.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: كان صعباً، ولكن على أي حال نجحنا.

note: Used to emphasize negation or inclusiveness.

example_sentences.translation_english: I am not tired at all.
In general, how was your day?
They went out for a walk together.
The store is opposite the bank.

example_sentences.hebrew: הוא לא יודע מֵאַיִן הגיע הרעש.
example_sentences.translation_english: He doesn't know where the noise came from.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: لا يعرف من أين جاء الضجيج.

note: Masculine form of 'which' or 'what kind of'.

example_sentences.translation_english: Which book are you reading? (masculine noun)
What kind of car do you have? (feminine noun)
Which things did you bring? (plural noun)

example_sentences.hebrew: הוא הולך לְאָן שֶׁלֹּא רוצים אותו.
example_sentences.translation_english: He goes wherever they don't want him.

note: Followed by the infinitive.

example_sentences.translation_english: I am studying in order to know more.
He worked hard in order to succeed.

example_sentences.hebrew: הם בילו את החג עם הַמִּשְׁפָּחוֹת שלהם.
example_sentences.translation_english: They spent the holiday with their families.

note: Singular form (gender-neutral/masculine).

example_sentences.hebrew: כל תלמיד צריך להביא הוֹרֶה לפגישה.
example_sentences.translation_english: Every student needs to bring a parent to the meeting.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: كل طالب يحتاج لإحضار أحد الوالدين للاجتماع.

example_sentences.translation_english: The mothers talked to each other.

note: Also means 'nurse'.

example_sentences.translation_english: The nurses are working at the hospital.

note: Informal.

example_sentences.translation_english: My grandma is coming to visit.

note: Informal.
Also means 'owner' or 'master'.

example_sentences.translation_english: Who is the owner of this dog?

note: Can mean woman or wife.

example_sentences.translation_english: We saw many men at the event.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: رأينا الكثير من الرجال في الحدث.

note: Often used with a preposition, e.g., בְּיֶתֶר (beyeter) 'in excess', 'especially'.

example_sentences.translation_english: We walked on the path in the forest.
There are many walking trails here.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: يوجد الكثير من مسارات المشي هنا.

example_sentences.translation_english: Children love to play in the snow.

note: Can mean wind or spirit.

example_sentences.translation_english: There is a strong wind today.
There is a big cloud in the sky.
The sky is full of clouds.

note: Can mean clock or watch.

example_sentences.translation_english: What time is it? (Literally: What is the clock?)

example_sentences.hebrew: אנחנו צריכים לְתַדְלֵק, אין מספיק דֶּלֶק.
example_sentences.translation_english: We need to refuel, there isn't enough fuel.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: نحن بحاجة للتزود بالوقود، لا يوجد وقود كافٍ.

example_sentences.translation_english: The price of fuel went up.
There is no electricity in the building.
She is cooking in the kitchen.
We have two kitchens in the house.
We sat on the bench in the park.
There are many benches in the garden.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: يوجد الكثير من المقاعد في الحديقة.

example_sentences.translation_english: I'm tired, I'm going to bed.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: أنا متعب، أنا ذاهب إلى السرير.

example_sentences.translation_english: There are three beds in the room.

note: Can mean wardrobe, closet, or cupboard.

example_sentences.translation_english: The clothes are in the wardrobe.
There are many cupboards in the kitchen.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: يوجد الكثير من الخزائن في المطبخ.

example_sentences.translation_english: The book is on the shelf.
This is a borrowed pen (masculine noun).
The books are borrowed from the library (plural noun).
You are invited to the party (masculine).
Is it allowed to smoke here?
This is allowed according to the law.
It is forbidden to park here.

note: More common in poetry or older texts; יָפֶה (yafe) is more common.
Often used in compound nouns like מְעוֹן יוֹמִי (me'on yomi) 'daycare'.
Always plural in Hebrew.

example_sentences.translation_english: They rode bicycles in the park.
What is the title of the book?
I read the headlines in the newspaper.
The food has a good taste.
He has good taste in clothes.
There is a pleasant smell of flowers.
There were different smells in the room.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: كانت توجد روائح مختلفة في الغرفة.

example_sentences.translation_english: The wind is blowing from the north.
The sun rises in the east.
The sun sets in the west.
The wind is blowing to the west.

note: Literally 'outside the land'.
Refers to the Land of Israel.

example_sentences.translation_english: They made Aliyah (immigrated to the Land of Israel).
The stories of the Bible take place in the Land of Israel.
example_sentences.translation_arabic: قصص التوراة تحدث في أرض إسرائيل.

note: Can also mean 'available' or 'empty'.

example_sentences.translation_english: This is an important thing (masculine noun).
This is an important task (feminine noun).
This is an easy test (masculine noun).
This is a difficult question (feminine noun).
He is a difficult person (masculine noun).
He is a strong man (masculine noun).
She has a strong spirit (feminine noun).
She was weak after the illness (feminine).
This is a pleasant day (masculine noun).
This is an unpleasant situation (masculine noun).
It was awkward for me to ask.
He is a known/famous writer (masculine noun).
This is a known fact (feminine noun).
This is an unknown reason (feminine noun).

note: Can mean straight, honest, or directly.

example_sentences.translation_english: He is an honest person (masculine noun).
The glass is full of water (masculine noun).
This is a normal day (masculine noun).
This is a regular conversation (feminine noun).
This is a special day (masculine noun).
She has a special ability (feminine noun).

note: Refers to dietary laws (Kosher) or sometimes means 'fit' or 'proper'.

example_sentences.translation_english: The food in this restaurant is kosher.
He was not fit for the role.

note: Opposite of kosher; refers to forbidden food according to Jewish law.

example_sentences.translation_arabic: هو لا يأكل طعاماً غير كوشير.

example_sentences.translation_english: She has a religious family (feminine noun).
She comes from a secular family (feminine noun).

note: Refers to traditional Jewish practice, often between fully religious and secular.

example_sentences.translation_english: He grew up in a traditional home (masculine).

note: Different word from טַעַם (taste); refers to a reason or argument.

note: Synonym for תַּעַם (reason).

example_sentences.translation_english: I don't have a good reason.

This is an important action (feminine noun).

note: Can mean permission, authority, or a public domain/authority.

example_sentences.translation_english: I have a lot of work.

note: Always plural in this context.

note: Plural form.

note: Central text of Rabbinic Judaism.

note: Religious school/academy, primarily for studying Talmud.
